com.bergerkiller.bukkit.common.conversion

Interface Converter<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - output type
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    BasicConverter, CastingConverter, CollectionConverter, CollectionTypeConverter, EmptyConverter, EmptyConverterUnsafe, EntryConverter, EnumConverter, HandleConverter, NumberConverter, ObjectArrayConverter, PrimitiveArrayConverter, PrimitiveConverter, PropertyConverter, WrapperConverter, WrapperHandleConverter

    public interface Converter<T>
    Represents a data type converter

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      <K> Converter<K> cast(java.lang.Class<K> type)
      Creates a new Converter that uses this base converter, but attempts to cast the result to the type specified
      T convert(java.lang.Object value)
      Converts the input value to the output type
      If conversion fails, null is returned instead
      T convert(java.lang.Object value, T def)
      Converts the input value to the output type
      <K> ConverterPair<T,K> formPair(Converter<K> converterB)
      Creates a new ConverterPair with this converter as A and the specified converter as B
      java.lang.Class<T> getOutputType()
      Gets the Class type returned by convert
      boolean isCastingSupported()
      Checks whether the returned output value can be casted to another type
      This should only be supported when the returned type can be an extension of the output type
      Typically, interfaces do not support this, as they can conflict with other converters

      Do not give a converter for multipurpose types this property!
      boolean isRegisterSupported()
      Checks whether this converter supports registering in the Conversion look-up table.

      • getOutputType

      • isCastingSupported

        boolean isCastingSupported()
        Checks whether the returned output value can be casted to another type
        This should only be supported when the returned type can be an extension of the output type
        Typically, interfaces do not support this, as they can conflict with other converters

        Do not give a converter for multipurpose types this property! For example, an Object converter would end up being used for all cases, rendering isCastingSupported unusable globally.

        Returns:
        True if casting is supported, False if not

      • isRegisterSupported

        boolean isRegisterSupported()
        Checks whether this converter supports registering in the Conversion look-up table. If this converter produces something that has to do with reading a field or method, and not actual conversion, this should be set to True.
        Returns:
        True if Conversion table registration is enabled, False if not

      • formPair

        <K> ConverterPair<T,K> formPair(Converter<K> converterB)
        Creates a new ConverterPair with this converter as A and the specified converter as B
        Parameters:
        converterB - to form a pair with
        Returns:
        new ConverterPair

      • cast

        <K> Converter<K> cast(java.lang.Class<K> type)
        Creates a new Converter that uses this base converter, but attempts to cast the result to the type specified
        Parameters:
        type - to cast to
        Returns:
        new Casting Converter
